body:
# Add "Import Markdown" Feature to Admin Editor

When creating a new post, you currently have to manually fill in every field (title, slug, tags, body, etc.). This feature adds an **"Import .md"** button that lets you paste or upload a raw markdown file and have it auto-populate the editor form.

## How It Works

1. A new **"import .md"** button appears in the AdminEditor header (next to the preview toggle) when creating a new post
2. Clicking it opens a small modal with a textarea where you paste your [.md](file:///c:/Users/ahmed/OneDrive/Documents/GitHub/myweb/SETUP.md) file content
3. The parser extracts:
   - **Title** → from the first `# heading`
   - **Body** → the full markdown content
   - **Excerpt** → first paragraph after the title (auto-truncated to ~200 chars)
   - **Slug** → auto-generated from the title
   - **Read time** → estimated from word count (~200 words/min)
4. You review/adjust the auto-filled fields (category, tags, etc.), then save as normal

## Proposed Changes

### AdminEditor Component

#### [MODIFY] [AdminEditor.tsx](file:///c:/Users/ahmed/OneDrive/Documents/GitHub/myweb/components/AdminEditor.tsx)

- Add `FileUp` icon import from lucide-react
- Add `showImport` state toggle
- Add `handleImportMarkdown(mdText: string)` function that parses the markdown and fills the form:
  - Extracts title from first `# ` line
  - Sets body to the full markdown text
  - Auto-generates slug, excerpt, and read time
- Add an **"import .md"** button in the modal header (visible only for new posts)
- Add a collapsible import panel with a textarea + "apply" button, shown when `showImport` is true

No new files or dependencies needed — this is a self-contained addition to the existing component.

## Verification Plan

### Manual Verification
1. Run `npm run dev` and go to `http://localhost:3000/admin`
2. Log in with GitHub credentials
3. Click **"new post"**
4. Click **"import .md"** button in the editor header
5. Paste the contents of [bc-restore-production-license-fix.md.resolved](file:///c:/Users/ahmed/OneDrive/Documents/GitHub/myweb/bc-restore-production-license-fix.md.resolved) into the import textarea
6. Click "apply" — verify the title, slug, excerpt, body, and read time fields are auto-filled
7. Adjust category/tags as needed, then save

title: Setting Up Business Central in Docker for Local Development
excerpt: Step-by-step guide to running Business Central in Docker using BcContainerHelper â the fastest way to get a local BC development environment.
body:
# Setting Up Business Central in Docker for Local Development

Running Business Central locally in Docker is the fastest way to develop and test AL extensions without needing a cloud sandbox.

## Prerequisites

- **Docker Desktop** for Windows (with Windows containers)
- **PowerShell 5.1+**
- **BcContainerHelper** PowerShell module
- At least 8GB RAM (16GB recommended)

## Install BcContainerHelper

```powershell
Install-Module BcContainerHelper -Force
Import-Module BcContainerHelper
```

## Create a BC Container

```powershell
$params = @{
  containerName      = 'bcdev'
  imageName          = 'mcr.microsoft.com/businesscentral:sandbox'
  accept_eula        = $true
  accept_outdated    = $true
  auth               = 'UserPassword'
  credential         = (New-Object PSCredential 'admin',
                        (ConvertTo-SecureString 'Password1!' -AsPlainText -Force))
  updateHosts        = $true
  licenseFile        = 'C:\bc\license.flf'
}

New-BcContainer @params
```

## Useful BcContainerHelper Commands

```powershell
# Publish an extension
Publish-BcContainerApp -containerName 'bcdev' `
  -appFile '.\output\MyApp.app' `
  -skipVerification

# Run AL tests
Run-TestsInBcContainer -containerName 'bcdev' `
  -extensionId (Get-BcContainerAppInfo 'bcdev' | 
    Where-Object { $_.Name -eq 'MyApp' }).AppId

# Get container logs
Get-BcContainerEventLog -containerName 'bcdev'
```

## Connect VS Code to Your Container

Update your `launch.json`:
```json
{
  "server": "http://bcdev",
  "authentication": "UserPassword",
  "credential": {
    "userName": "admin",
    "password": "Password1!"
  }
}
```

## Troubleshooting Tips

- **Container won't start?** Check Windows container mode in Docker Desktop
- **License errors?** Ensure your `.flf` license file is for the correct BC version
- **Slow startup?** First pull of the image takes 10-20 minutes â subsequent restarts are fast

title: Getting Started with AL Development in Business Central
excerpt: A comprehensive guide to setting up your AL development environment and writing your first extension for Microsoft Dynamics 365 Business Central.
body:
# Getting Started with AL Development in Business Central

Microsoft Dynamics 365 Business Central uses the **AL programming language** for all customizations and extensions. This guide walks you through setting up your environment and writing your first extension.

## Prerequisites

Before you begin, you'll need:
- **VS Code** with the AL Language extension
- **Business Central sandbox** environment (or Docker container)
- Basic understanding of object-oriented programming

## Setting Up Your Environment

### 1. Install VS Code Extensions

Install the following VS Code extensions:
```bash
# Search in VS Code marketplace:
- AL Language (by Microsoft)
- AZ AL Dev Tools/AL Code Outline
- CRS AL Language Extension
```

### 2. Configure launch.json

```json
{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "type": "al",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "Your own server",
      "server": "https://yourtenant.dynamics.com",
      "tenant": "your-tenant-id",
      "authentication": "AAD"
    }
  ]
}
```

## Your First AL Object

Here's a simple table extension to get you started:

```al
tableextension 50100 "MyCustomer Extension" extends Customer
{
  fields
  {
    field(50100; "Custom Field"; Text[100])
    {
      Caption = 'Custom Field';
      DataClassification = CustomerContent;
    }
  }
}
```

## Key Concepts

- **Object IDs**: Always use IDs in the 50000-99999 range for custom objects
- **Data Classification**: Always set this for GDPR compliance
- **Event-driven**: Use events for extensibility rather than modifying base objects

## Next Steps

Once you're comfortable with basic objects, explore:
1. Page extensions and page customizations
2. Codeunits for business logic
3. Report extensions
4. API pages for integrations
